items.label: def-mean-field-phase-space
items.title: Phase Space
items.content:
42: Let $X_{\text{valid}} \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ be the bounded, convex domain with a $C^2$ boundary, and let $V_{\text{alg}} := \{v \in \mathbb{R}^d : \|v\| \le V_{\text{alg}}\}$ be the closed ball of allowed velocities, as defined in the Euclidean Gas specification (*Chapter 2, Sec. 1.1*).
 43: 
 44: The single-particle **phase space**, denoted $\Omega$, is the Cartesian product of the valid position and velocity domains:
 45: 
 46: $$
 47: \Omega := X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}
 48: $$
 49:

items.label: def-phase-space-density
items.title: Phase-Space Density
items.content:
64: The state of the swarm's **alive population** at time $t \ge 0$ is described by the **phase-space sub-probability density** $f: [0, \infty) \times \Omega \to [0, \infty)$. For any time $t$, $f(t, \cdot, \cdot)$ is a function on the phase space such that for any measurable subset $A \subseteq \Omega$, the mass of alive walkers in $A$ is given by the integral:
 65: 
 66: $$
 67: \text{Alive mass in } A = \int_A f(t, z) dz.
 68: $$
 69: 
 70: Just as integrating a city's population density over a neighborhood gives the number of people living there, integrating $f$ over a region of phase space gives the fraction of alive walkers expected to be in that region.
 71: 
 72: The integral of this density gives the total mass of alive walkers, $m_a(t)$:
 73: 
 74: $$
 75: m_a(t) := \int_{\Omega} f(t,x,v)\,\mathrm{d}x\,\mathrm{d}v \le 1
 76: $$
 77: 
 78: The mass of dead walkers is then given by $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$. The evolution of the system will be described by a coupled system for $f(t,z)$ and $m_d(t)$ that conserves the total mass $m_a(t) + m_d(t) = 1$.
 79: 
 80: We assume that $f$ has sufficient regularity for all subsequent operations to be well-defined, namely $f \in C([0, \infty); L^1(\Omega))$.

items.label: def-mean-field-moments
items.title: Mean-Field Statistical Moments
items.content:
119: Let $f(t, \cdot)$ be the phase-space density at time $t$, with total alive mass $m_a(t) = \int_\Omega f(t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z$. The statistical moments required for the standardization pipeline are defined as the following **functionals** of $f$. The notation $\mu[f]$ emphasizes that these are numbers that depend on the entire *shape* of the function $f$.
120: 
121: The moments are computed with respect to the **normalized density of the alive population**, which is $f(t,z) / m_a(t)$. This normalization is critical for ensuring the mean-field model is a faithful limit of the N-particle system, where statistics are computed by averaging over the $k$ alive walkers.
122: 
123: *   **Reward Moments:** The mean reward, $\mu_R[f]$, is computed as the expected value over the normalized alive population:
124: 
125:     $$
126:     \mu_R[f](t) := \int_{\Omega} R(z) \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)}\,\mathrm dz
127:     $$
128: 
129:     $$
130:     \sigma_R^2[f](t) := \int_{\Omega} \bigl(R(z) - \mu_R[f](t)\bigr)^2 \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)}\,\mathrm dz
131:     $$
132: 
133: *   **Distance Moments:** The mean distance is the expectation of the distance between two particles drawn independently from the normalized alive population:
134: 
135:     $$
136:     \mu_D[f](t) := \iint_{\Omega \times \Omega} d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z), \varphi(z')) \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} \frac{f(t,z')}{m_a(t)}\,\mathrm dz\,\mathrm dz'
137:     $$
138: 
139:     $$
140:     \sigma_D^2[f](t) := \iint_{\Omega \times \Omega} \bigl(d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z), \varphi(z')) - \mu_D[f](t)\bigr)^2 \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)} \frac{f(t,z')}{m_a(t)}\,\mathrm dz\,\mathrm dz'
141:     $$

items.label: def-mean-field-patched-std
items.title: Mean-Field Regularized Standard Deviation
items.content:
179: The **Mean-Field Regularized Standard Deviations** are functionals of the density $f$, obtained by applying the `Regularized Standard Deviation` function from the abstract framework (*Chapter 1, Def. 11.1.2*) to the mean-field variance functionals:
180: 
181: $$
182: \widehat{\sigma}_R[f](t) := \sigma\'_{\text{reg}}(\sigma_R^2[f](t)), \qquad \widehat{\sigma}_D[f](t) := \sigma\'_{\text{reg}}(\sigma_D^2[f](t))
183: $$
184: This ensures that the denominators in the mean-field standardization are also uniformly bounded away from zero, preserving the crucial stability properties of the discrete system.

items.label: def-mean-field-z-scores
items.title: Mean-Field Z-Scores
items.content:
196: For a particle at state $z$ and a potential companion at state $z_c$, the mean-field Z-scores at time $t$ are defined using the density-dependent functionals derived in Section 1.2:
197: 
198: $$
199: \widetilde{r}[f](z,t) := \frac{R(z) - \mu_R[f](t)}{\widehat{\sigma}_R[f](t)}, \qquad \widetilde{d}[f](z,z_c,t) := \frac{d_{\mathcal{Y}}(\varphi(z),\varphi(z_c)) - \mu_D[f](t)}{\widehat{\sigma}_D[f](t)}
200: $$
201: These Z-scores measure how many "global standard deviations" a particle's raw reward or its distance to a companion is from the swarm's current average. A positive Z-score indicates an above-average measurement.

items.label: def-mean-field-fitness-potential
items.title: Mean-Field Fitness Potential
items.content:
209: The **Mean-Field Fitness Potential**, denoted $V[f](z, z_c, t)$, is a functional of the density $f$ that determines the fitness of a particle at state $z$ relative to a companion at $z_c$. It is constructed by applying the canonical `Rescale Transformation` $g_A$ (*Chapter 1, Sec. 8*) to the mean-field Z-scores:
210: 
211: $$
212: V[f](z,z_c,t) := \left(g_A(\widetilde{d}[f](z,z_c,t)) + \eta\right)^{\beta} \cdot \left(g_A(\widetilde{r}[f](z,t)) + \eta\right)^{\alpha}
213: $$
214: This potential inherits the floor from the N-particle algorithm, ensuring it is always strictly positive.

items.label: def-baoab-update-rule
items.title: The BAOAB Update Rule
items.content:
258: For a single particle with state $(x_n, v_n)$ at time $t_n$, the state $(x_{n+1}, v_{n+1})$ at time $t_{n+1} = t_n + \tau$ is computed via the following five steps:
259: 
260: 1.  **B-Step (Force Kick):** The velocity is updated with a half-step kick from the conservative force $F(x)$.
261: 
262:     $$
263:     v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} = v_n + \frac{\tau}{2m} F(x_n)
264:     $$
265: 
266: 2.  **A-Step (Position Drift):** The position is updated with a half-step drift using the new velocity.
267: 
268:     $$
269:     x_{n+1/2} = x_n + \frac{\tau}{2} v_{n+1/2}^{(1)}
270:     $$
271: 
272: 3.  **O-Step (Ornstein-Uhlenbeck):** The velocity is updated for a full timestep by exactly solving the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process that combines friction and thermal noise. Let $u_{n+1/2} = u(x_{n+1/2})$ be the flow field evaluated at the midpoint.
273: 
274:     $$
275:     v_{n+1/2}^{(2)} = u_{n+1/2} + e^{-\gamma_{\mathrm{fric}}\tau}\left(v_{n+1/2}^{(1)} - u_{n+1/2}\right) + \sqrt{\frac{\Theta}{m}(1 - e^{-2\gamma_{\mathrm{fric}}\tau})} \cdot \xi
276:     $$
277:     where $\xi \sim \mathcal{N}(0, I_d)$ is a standard Gaussian random vector.
278: 
279: 4.  **A-Step (Position Drift):** The position is updated with a final half-step drift.
280: 
281:     $$
282:     x_{n+1} = x_{n+1/2} + \frac{\tau}{2} v_{n+1/2}^{(2)}
283:     $$
284: 
285: 5.  **B-Step (Force Kick):** The velocity is updated with a final half-step kick using the force evaluated at the new position, $F(x_{n+1})$.
286: 
287:     $$
288:     v_{n+1} = v_{n+1/2}^{(2)} + \frac{\tau}{2m} F(x_{n+1})
289:     $$
290: 
291: An optional velocity cap, $\psi_v$, is applied after the final B-step to ensure $v_{n+1} \in V_{\text{alg}}$, maintaining perfect fidelity with the discrete algorithm's definition.

items.label: def-kinetic-generator
items.title: Kinetic Transport Operator
items.content:
314: The kinetic evolution of a single alive walker $i$ is governed by the underdamped Langevin SDE on the phase space $\Omega$:
315: 
316: $$
317: \mathrm d x_i = v_i\,\mathrm dt,\qquad
318: \mathrm d v_i = \left(\frac{1}{m}F(x_i)-\gamma_{\mathrm{fric}}(v_i-u(x_i))\right)\,\mathrm dt \;+\; \sigma_v\,\mathrm dW_t
319: $$
320: 
321: where $W_t$ is a standard $d$-dimensional Wiener process and the parameters are those of the Euclidean Gas. This SDE is subject to **reflecting boundary conditions** on both position and velocity:
322: 
323: 1.  **Reflecting Position Boundary:** Trajectories reflect at the boundary $\partial X_{\text{valid}}$, ensuring no mass leaves the domain through kinetic transport. This models the pure kinetic portion of the dynamics with a simple, local boundary condition.
324: 2.  **Reflecting Velocity Boundary:** The dynamics are constrained to the velocity ball $V_{\text{alg}}$. This is modeled by a reflecting or squash boundary condition at $\|v\|=V_{\text{alg}}$ that mirrors the action of the velocity cap $\psi_v$.
325: 
326: The infinitesimal generator for the N-particle system under this collection of independent SDEs is the **Fokker-Planck operator**, which acts on a test function $f$ on the swarm state space. For the set of alive walkers $\mathcal{A}$, it is given by:
327: 
328: $$
329: \boxed{
330: \mathcal{L}_{\text{kin}} f = \sum_{i\in\mathcal A}\left[ v_i\cdot\nabla_{x_i} f + \left(m^{-1}F(x_i)-\gamma_{\mathrm{fric}}(v_i-u(x_i))\right)\cdot\nabla_{v_i} f + \tfrac{\sigma_v^2}{2}\,\Delta_{v_i} f\right]
331: }
332: $$
333: 
334: A key property of this operator with reflecting boundary conditions is that it is **mass-conservative**: when integrated over the domain, the total flux through the boundary vanishes, so $\int_\Omega L^\dagger f \,\mathrm{d}z = 0$.

items.label: def-killing-operator
items.title: Interior Killing Operator
items.content:
363: Death is modeled by an **interior killing rate** $c: \Omega \to [0, \infty)$, a smooth, non-negative function with the following properties:
364: 
365: 1.  **Safety in the interior**: $c(z) = 0$ for all $z$ in a safe subset of $\Omega$ away from the position boundary.
366: 2.  **Activity near the boundary**: $c(z) > 0$ in a smooth transition layer near $\partial X_{\text{valid}} \times V_{\text{alg}}$.
367: 3.  **Smoothness**: $c \in C^\infty(\Omega)$ to ensure regularity of the PDE solutions.
368: 
369: The killing operator removes mass from the alive density $f$ at a rate $c(z)f(z)$. The **total mass killed per unit time** is a functional of $f$:
370: 
371: $$
372: k_{\text{killed}}[f](t) := \int_{\Omega} c(z) f(t,z) \, \mathrm{d}z
373: $$
374: 
375: This is the instantaneous rate at which alive mass transitions to dead mass.

items.label: def-revival-operator
items.title: Revival Operator
items.content:
381: Revival is modeled as a source term that re-injects mass from the dead population back into the alive population. The dead population acts as a reservoir from which revival occurs at a constant rate. Dead walkers are instantly revived by cloning from alive companions, so the spatial profile of the re-injected mass is simply **proportional to the current alive density**, mirroring the discrete algorithm's revival mechanism.
382: 
383: The **Revival Operator** is defined as:
384: 
385: $$
386: B[f, m_d](t, z) := \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t) \cdot \frac{f(t,z)}{m_a(t)}
387: $$
388: 
389: where:
390: *   $\lambda_{\text{revive}} > 0$ is the **revival rate**, a free parameter independent of the timestep (typical values: 0.1-5)
391: *   $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$ is the current dead mass
392: *   $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$ is the **normalized alive density** (the probability distribution over the alive population)
393: 
394: This form directly translates the discrete algorithm: dead walkers select companions uniformly from the alive set and clone to their positions.
395: 
396: **Key property**: The total mass revived per unit time is:
397: 
398: $$
399: \int_{\Omega} B[f, m_d](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z = \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t)
400: $$
401: 
402: since the normalized alive density integrates to unity: $\int_\Omega [f/m_a]\,\mathrm{d}z = 1$.

391: *   $m_d(t) = 1 - m_a(t)$ is the current dead mass
392: *   $f(t,z)/m_a(t)$ is the **normalized alive density** (the probability distribution over the alive population)
393: 
394: This form directly translates the discrete algorithm: dead walkers select companions uniformly from the alive set and clone to their positions.
395: 
396: **Key property**: The total mass revived per unit time is:
397: 
398: $$
399: \int_{\Omega} B[f, m_d](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z = \lambda_{\text{revive}} \cdot m_d(t)
400: $$
401: 
402: since the normalized alive density integrates to unity: $\int_\Omega [f/m_a]\,\mathrm{d}z = 1$.
403: :::

items.label: def-cloning-generator
items.title: Internal Cloning Operator (Derived Form)
items.content:
500: The **Internal Cloning Operator**, $S[f]$, is the mean-field limit of the discrete cloning mechanism. It is a mass-neutral, non-local operator that decomposes into sink and source terms:
501: 
502: $$
503: S[f](t, z) = S_{\text{src}}[f](t, z) - S_{\text{sink}}[f](t, z)
504: $$
505: 
506: where:
507: 
508: *   **Sink** (mass removed when walkers at $z$ clone away):
509: 
510:     $$
511:     S_{\text{sink}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau} f(t,z) \int_{\Omega} P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z, z_c) \frac{f(t,z_c)}{m_a(t)} \,\mathrm{d}z_c
512:     $$
513: 
514: *   **Source** (mass gained when walkers from other states clone to $z$):
515: 
516:     $$
517:     S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z) = \frac{1}{\tau m_a(t)} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(t,z_d) f(t,z_c) P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c) Q_{\delta}(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c
518:     $$
519: 
520: Here:
521: - $P_{\text{clone}}[f/m_a](z_d, z_c)$ is the cloning probability depending on fitness values computed from the normalized alive density $f/m_a$
522: - $Q_\delta(z \mid z_c)$ is the jitter kernel (Gaussian in position, delta in velocity)
523: - $\tau$ is the discrete timestep, and $1/\tau$ converts per-step probabilities to continuous rates
524: 
525: **Key property**: The operator is mass-neutral by construction. To verify, integrate over $\Omega$:
526: 
527: $$
528: \begin{aligned}
529: \int_{\Omega} S[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z &= \int_{\Omega} S_{\text{src}}[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z - \int_{\Omega} S_{\text{sink}}[f](t,z)\,\mathrm{d}z \\
530: &= \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) Q_\delta(z \mid z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z\,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c \\
531: &\quad - \frac{1}{\tau} \int_{\Omega} f(z) \int_{\Omega} P(z, z_c) \frac{f(z_c)}{m_a} \,\mathrm{d}z_c\,\mathrm{d}z
532: \end{aligned}
533: $$
534: 
535: Using $\int_\Omega Q_\delta(z \mid z_c)\,\mathrm{d}z = 1$:
536: 
537: $$
538: = \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c - \frac{1}{\tau m_a} \int_{\Omega} \int_{\Omega} f(z_d) f(z_c) P(z_d, z_c) \,\mathrm{d}z_d\,\mathrm{d}z_c = 0
539: $$
540: 
541: Thus $\int_{\Omega} S[f]\,\mathrm{d}z = 0$, confirming mass conservation.

items.label: def-transport-operator
items.title: Transport Operator and Probability Flux
items.content:
557: Let $L$ be the backward kinetic generator from Section 2.2. The **Transport Operator**, denoted $L^\dagger$, is its formal $L^2$-adjoint, which acts on the density $f$. It can be written in conservative form as the negative divergence of a **probability flux vector** $J = (J_x, J_v)$:
558: 
559: $$
560: L^\dagger f = -\nabla \cdot J[f] = -\nabla_x \cdot J_x[f] - \nabla_v \cdot J_v[f]
561: $$
562: 
563: where the components of the flux are:
564: *   **Positional Flux ($J_x$):** $J_x[f] := v f - D_x \nabla_x f$ (Advection + Fickian Diffusion)
565: *   **Velocity Flux ($J_v$):** $J_v[f] := A_v f - D_v \nabla_v f$ (Drift + Fickian Diffusion)
566: 
567: and $A_v$ is the velocity drift field from the Langevin dynamics.
